Scenes from the Life of Christ

Probably executed by local craftsmen as a high altarpiece for Norwich Cathedral during the episcopate of Henry Despencer (Bishop of Norwich 1370-1406), since the frame bears his arms along with the arms of prominent Norwich families who may have financed the reconstruction of the eastern part of the cathedral. (This Despencer Retable has survived, although damaged, because it was used as a tabletop until 1847).

column5: Ascension. In subject, the altarpiece resembles some altarpieces of alabaster panels. In style, the cramped foreground space, the attenuated figures, with large heavily-modelled heads, and the background of stamped gesso patterning, are very much of the period, c.1380-1400. A similar fusion of Netherlandish and Italianate elements marks the manuscripts associated with the Bohun family (see Images 355,393, 579) and the Lytlington Missal. For an image of the centre of the central, Crucifixion, panel, see Image 186. An unusual feature of the Ascension panel is that the disappearing Christ ascends in a mandorla.
